message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Zidovudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor that interferes with viral DNA elongation. This helps to reduce perinatal transmission of the virus by lowering the amount of virus in the mother's bloodstream during birth. Integration of viral genome, cleavage of viral polypeptides, and fusion of virus with T cells are not affected by zidovudine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Zidovudine (AZT) is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI), which works by inhibiting the elongation of viral DNA during reverse transcription. Therefore, the most likely process affected by this drug is elongation of viral DNA. This reduces the risk of perinatal transmission of HIV. Integration of viral genome occurs after elongation of viral DNA, and cleavage of viral polypeptides and fusion of virus with T cells are not targeted by this drug.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intravenous zidovudine is an antiretroviral drug used to reduce perinatal transmission of HIV. It inhibits the elongation of viral DNA. Integrase inhibitors inhibit integration of viral genome, protease inhibitors inhibit cleavage of viral polypeptides, and fusion inhibitors inhibit fusion of virus with T cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Zidovudine works by inhibiting the elongation of viral DNA. This reduces the viral load and helps reduce perinatal transmission of HIV. Integration of viral genome, cleavage of viral polypeptides, and fusion of virus with T cells are not affected by this drug.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Zidovudine is a reverse transcriptase inhibitor that inhibits the elongation of viral DNA during the replication process of HIV, hence reducing perinatal transmission of the virus to the fetus. Integration of viral genome is the process where the viral DNA integrates into the host genome. Cleavage of viral polypeptides is the process where the newly synthesized viral proteins are cleaved into active forms. Fusion of the virus with T cells is the process where the virus binds and enters into the target T cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Zidovudine (AZT) is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) which inhibits the elongation of viral DNA during reverse transcription of HIV. It does not affect the integration of viral genome, cleavage of viral polypeptides, or fusion of virus with T cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Zidovudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor and it inhibits the elongation of viral DNA during reverse transcription. This reduces the amount of HIV transferred from the mother to the fetus during childbirth. Integration of viral genome occurs after reverse transcription, and cleavage of viral polypeptides and fusion of virus with T cells occur during viral replication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Zidovudine works by inhibiting reverse transcriptase, which is responsible for elongation of viral DNA. This reduces the replication of HIV, thus reducing the risk of perinatal transmission. Integration of viral genome, cleavage of viral polypeptides, and fusion of virus with T cells are not affected by this drug.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Zidovudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor that inhibits elongation of viral DNA, which reduces viral replication and perinatal transmission of HIV. Integration of viral genome and cleavage of viral polypeptides are not affected by zidovudine, and fusion of virus with T cells is an early step in HIV infection, not affected by this drug.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Zidovudine, also known as AZT, is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that inhibits the elongation of viral DNA during reverse transcription. It does not affect the integration of viral genome, cleavage of viral polypeptides, or fusion of virus with T cells.
